title: LLMPopcorn: An Empirical Study of LLMs as Assistants for Popular Micro-video Generation
author: Junchen Fu (University of Glasgow), Xuri Ge (Shandong University), Kaiwen Zheng (University of Glasgow), Ioannis Arapakis (Telefónica Scientific Research), Xin Xin (Shandong University), Joemon M. Jose (University of Glasgow), ...
relevance_why: The paper explores the use of Large Language Models (LLMs) to enhance content generation, which could inform methods for audio generation and multimodal integration in Haohe Liu's work.
background: Utilizing advanced LLMs to assist in generating popular short videos by structuring prompts that cater to trends, aiming to optimize audience engagement.
contribution: LLMPopcorn introduces a pipeline leveraging LLMs for generating enhanced video content, striving to improve the popularity of micro-videos comparable to human-created content.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing video generation methods mainly focus on video quality and content but overlook popular engagement factors.
technical_comparison.novelty: This study integrates LLMs specifically for enhancing the popularity of video content by developing a streamlined generation and evaluation pipeline.

key_innovation: The author proposes a unique pipeline that combines LLM-based prompt generation with video popularity prediction to facilitate the creation of engaging micro-videos.
real_world_impact: This approach has potential applications in content creation, particularly on platforms like TikTok and YouTube, enhancing how videos are produced and consumed.
limitations: While generating videos that sometimes exceed human benchmarks in predicted popularity, the overall absolute scores remain modest.

new_terms.LLMs: **Large Language Models** are advanced AI systems trained on extensive text data that can generate, summarize, and translate text, enhancing creative and contextual capabilities.
new_terms.micro-videos: **Micro-videos** are short video content pieces typically under one minute long, widely consumed on social media platforms.

open_sourcing: Code and datasets will be released to support future studies.
